titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Stock and Rettberg family papers 1979.007
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-28 19:55:46 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection contains the papers of the Stock and Rettberg families who rented a house at 61 Court Street, Brooklyn around 1872. Documents include legal documentation (leases, deeds, bonds, and receipts), documents relating to the death of Ernst Rettberg, a certificate of copyright for Lina Rettberg, and one photograph.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Brooklyn Museum, date unknown. The papers were formally accessioned in 1979.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement. Oversize materials are housed separately.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Stock and Rettberg family papers, 1979.007, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the papers of the Stock and Rettberg families who rented a house at 61 Court Street, Brooklyn around 1872. Documents include legal documentation (leases, deeds, bonds, and receipts), the death certificate of Ernst Rettberg, the inventory of the estate of Ernst Rettberg, a certificate of copyright for Lina Rettberg, and one photograph. The papers span the period 1866 to 1906.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
